title: 109_s2076
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorney Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005" and addresses the retirement treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The "Assistant United States Attorney Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to define an assistant United States attorney as an attorney under section 542 of title 28 or any other attorney employed by the Department. The "Assistant United States Attorney Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005" amends Chapter 83 of title 5, United States Code to include attorneys employed by the Department of Justice in critical positions similar to assistant United States attorneys for retirement benefits. The Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005 treats assistant United States attorneys as law enforcement officers for retirement benefits, with technical and conforming amendments made to Chapter 83 of title 5, United States Code. The Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005 classifies assistant United States attorneys as law enforcement officers for retirement benefits, with amendments made to Chapter 83 of title 5, United States Code, defining an assistant United States attorney as specified in Section 8401 of title 5, United States Code. The Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005 amends retirement treatment for assistant United States attorneys, ensuring they are treated similarly to assistant United States attorneys in terms of retirement benefits. The Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2005 ensures that assistant United States attorneys are treated similarly to law enforcement officers for retirement benefits. Amendments specify that mandatory separation rules do not apply to assistant United States attorneys. The effective date for these changes is the first day of the first applicable pay period after 120 days from the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. In this section, the term "assistant United States attorney" refers to attorneys under section 542 of title 28, United States Code, or any other attorney designated by the Attorney General with similar responsibilities critical to the Department of Justice. The term "incumbent" refers to individuals currently serving as assistant United States attorneys. The Attorney General must designate attorneys meeting specific criteria before a certain date, and the Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents within 9 months of the Act's enactment. Incumbents must be notified of their election rights and the consequences of timely or untimely elections under the Act. An incumbent can choose to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act never existed. Failure to make a timely election will be treated as an election made on the last allowable day. The election must be made within 120 days of receiving notice. The Act requires incumbents to make an election within 120 days of receiving notice. Service performed by an incumbent as an assistant United States attorney will be treated according to applicable provisions of subchapter III. The Act requires incumbents to make an election within 120 days of receiving notice. Service performed by an incumbent as an assistant United States attorney will be treated in accordance with applicable provisions of subchapter III or chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code, as amended by this Act. No other retroactive effect shall affect the terms or conditions of an individual's employment with respect to any period preceding the date of the election. An individual who elects under subsection (d) must deposit the difference in contributions for prior service with interest to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. Failure to make the deposit will not affect the creditability of prior service. The incumbent's law enforcement officer service will remain creditable, but the resulting annuity will be reduced similar to section 8334(d)(2)(B) of title 5, US Code. Prior service is defined as assistant US attorney service not exceeding 20 years before retirement deductions begin. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe necessary regulations. Personnel Management will establish regulations for implementing the Act, including determining interest on specified amounts. The section will become effective 120 days after the Act's enactment. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Office of Personnel Management, will establish regulations within 120 days of the Act's enactment for designating attorneys as assistant United States attorneys. The designation of attorneys under section 3(a)(1)(B) will be at the discretion of the Attorney General.
